Question: A 32-year-old Caucasian male presents with a sudden onset symptoms including a high fever of 101.8°F, chills, generalized body aches, and severe fatigue that began two days ago. He reports a dry cough that occasionally produces clear sputum, a mild sore throat, persistent headaches, and nasal congestion with sneezing. His vital signs show a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, blood pressure of 120/78 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. He appears visibly uncomfortable and tired, and he has been hydrating well despite his symptoms. He denies any shortness of breath or chest pain and reports recent exposure to a sick coworker. Based on these symptoms, what can the patient have?

Jane Smith, a 28-year-old African American female, presents with a severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a fever of 100.5°F that started three days ago. She reports swollen, tender lymph nodes in her neck, and a persistent headache. Upon examination, her tonsils appear red and swollen with white patches. Her vital signs include a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, blood pressure of 118/76 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Jane appears visibly uncomfortable and has been drinking fluids but finds it painful to eat. She denies any cough or nasal congestion and mentions that she has not had any recent illnesses or significant exposure to others who are sick. Based on these symptoms, what can the patient have?

Michael Johnson, a 45-year-old Hispanic male, presents with symptoms including auditory hallucinations, delusions of persecution, and disorganized thinking. He reports hearing voices that criticize him and believes that people are conspiring against him. Michael appears anxious and agitated, with difficulty maintaining a coherent conversation. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 82 beats per minute, blood pressure of 125/80 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. He has a flat affect and demonstrates poor eye contact. Michael has a history of mental sickness in his early 20s and has been inconsistently taking his prescribed antipsychotic medication. He denies any substance use but reports recent increased stress due to job loss. He has limited social support and lives alone. Based on these symptoms, what can the patient have?
